summary: This is a joint letter from the prosecution and defense in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case (S2 20 Cr. 330) submitted to Judge Nathan, regarding proposed juror strikes and including modifications to the defense's previous strikes. It is a procedural filing in the lead-up to Maxwell's trial.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Attorney at Cohen & Gresser LLP who sent the email submitting the joint letter to Judge Nathan regarding proposed juror strikes in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

persons.name: Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge (Judge Nathan) in the United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell case, to whom the joint letter regarding juror strikes is addressed.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell (S2 20 Cr. 330), which is the subject of the juror strike proceedings.

connections.description: Attorney Everdell is submitting a court filing (joint letter) to Judge Nathan in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.
Attorney Everdell is involved in the legal proceedings (submitting a joint letter on juror strikes) for the case against defendant Ghislaine Maxwell.
Judge Nathan is the presiding judge in the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Submission of Joint Letter on Juror Strikes
events.description: The prosecution and defense in the Ghislaine Maxwell case submit a joint letter to Judge Nathan regarding proposed juror strikes, including modifications to the defense's previous strikes.

keyFacts: The document is a joint letter from the parties in United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell (S2 20 Cr. 330) submitted to Judge Nathan.
The letter concerns proposed juror strikes for Maxwell's trial and includes modifications to the defense's previous strikes.
The email transmitting the letter was sent by attorney Christian Everdell of Cohen & Gresser LLP on November 14, 2021.
The document indicates ongoing pre-trial jury selection procedures in the lead-up to Ghislaine Maxwell's criminal trial.
